Award.AwardTitle: (M-DISC) Mathematics Discourse in Secondary Classrooms: A Case-Based Professional Development Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
DRL: DR K-12
PI: Herbel-Eisenmann

Abstract

The project Mathematical Discourse in Secondary Classrooms, led by faculty at Michigan State University and the University of Delaware, is developing and testing materials for professional development leaders to use in work with secondary mathematics teachers. The aim is to help those teachers analyze the discourse patterns of their own classrooms and improve their skills in creating discourse patterns that emphasizes high-level mathematical explanation, justification, and argumentation.

The basic hypothesis of the project is that engaging in carefully planned analyses of narrative and video cases and in action research focused on discourse can effectively support teachers in improving the discourse quality of their classroom instruction. The project builds on findings from prior work that has shown how meaningful educational experiences can empower secondary mathematics teachers to identify and change problematic classroom discourse patterns and create more productive experiences for students.

The project is preparing an introductory module, five constellations of activities built around narrative and video cases, and a module to help professional developers support secondary mathematics teachers in conduct of action research. Development is informed by "soft pilot" testing that leads to improvement of the professional development program.

The core research questions of the project concern the effects of the professional development program on teacher knowledge, beliefs, and classroom practice. Preliminary evidence about answers for those questions is provided by an external pilot test of the professional development program. The effects of the professional development are evaluated by analysis of data from pre- and post-assessments of teacher knowledge, beliefs, and classroom practice.

This project addresses the challenge of enhancing teacher abilities to deliver high quality mathematics instruction. By focusing on practices that raise the level of classroom discourse about mathematics, the results have the potential to enhance the learning experiences of all students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to design, pilot, and produce a set of professional development materials for secondary mathematics teachers. The materials focus on supporting secondary mathematics teachers' facilitation of mathematics classroom discourse through a 36-40 hour study group, followed by supporting them to identify and engage in action research based on areas related to classroom discourse the teachers wish to improve or change. By “discourse” we mean anything people do to communicate with one another, including speaking, writing, drawing symbols or other representations, gesturing and other nonverbal communication, and so on. We focus primarily on spoken and written language, but also incorporate information related to drawing and gesturing because they are central to communicating about mathematics.

The materials draw from current research on sociolinguistics, positioning theory, equity, and teacher professional development and offer a set of "teacher discourse moves" as well as two conceptual lenses through which teachers can interpret the use of these moves: productive discourse (to understand and consider how to support students in making meaningful mathematical contributions toward particular mathematical learning goals) and powerful discourse (to understand and consider students’ developing identities as mathematical learners, as well as how the activities, tasks and structures used in mathematics classrooms constitutes what mathematics is for students). Across the five years of funding, the study group materials were piloted internally by project members in two sites and revised, piloted by external leaders of professional development in two sites with support from project members and then revised again, and piloted by external leaders of professional development without support from project members and revised a final time. One additional long-term internal pilot that began in 2012 is still ongoing and involved the study group, followed by four years of cycles of action research. Each of these pilots involved intensive data collection and analysis in order to inform revisions to the materials.

Findings from these pilots suggested that teachers who engaged with these materials: a) expanded their understandings of what constitutes mathematical discourse; b) came to see their students in new ways that then resulted in different ways of valuing students and their perspectives; c) developed ways to collect data about student positioning and changed their practices based on students' perceptions of their experiences; and d) dramatically shifted their discourse practices and distributed authority in ways that supported students to speak more often and with longer turns, listen and respond to each other, voice their mistakes and what they learned from them, explore multiple representations and solution strategies, and engage in elaborating on others’ thinking. Additionally, the long-term pilot has suggested that having the teachers engage in cycles of action research over multiple years can also influence teachers’ sense of themselves as professionals and contributors to the knowledge base on mathematics teaching and learning. These materials, titled Mathematics discourse in secondary classroom: A practice-based multimedia resource for professional learning, will be published by Math Solutions in 2017.
